case_name: Private Ltd. Company v. State of Bihar, Certificate Officer and the Collector of Champaran

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 370 of 1969 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 370 of 1969. Under Article 32 of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: Petitioner is a Private Ltd. Company challenging validity of Cane Cess and Purchase tax levied for January 1968.

anchor.surface_text: K. Chatterjee, N. H. Hingorani and Rathin Das, for the appellant. N. Sinha, Solicitor General, R. K. Garg, S. C. Agarwal and S. S. Bhatnagar, for respondent number 1 The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKARIA, J.-In this petition under Article 32 of the Constitution, the petitioner, a Private Ltd. Company, challenges the validity of the Cane Cess and Purchase tax levied on it for the month of January, 1968.

facts.text: Respondents 1, 2 and 3 are the State of Bihar, Certificate Officer and the Collector of Champaran respectively.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents 1, 2 and 3 are the State of Bihar, Certificate Officer and the Collector of Champaran, respectively.

facts.text: Bihar Sugar Factories Control Act, 1937 (Act 7 of 1937) was in force as a pre-Constitution law levying cane cess and purchase tax.

anchor.surface_text: The facts are these There was in force in the State of Bihar a pre-Constitution law known as Bihar Sugar Factories Control Act, 1937  Act 7 of 1937 . By numberification issued under s. 29 of that Act, cane cess and purchase tax were being levied in respect of sugar cane intended to be used or used in a sugar factory.

facts.text: Act 7 of 1937 originally to remain in force until June 30, 1941, extended by amending Acts, last by Bihar Act 6 of 1950 upto January 30, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: It was a temporary enactment. Originally, it was to remain in force until June 30, 1941. But its life was extended from time to time by different amending Acts. The last extension was made by Bihar Act 6 of 1950 upto January 30, 1955, which came into force on January 9, 1950 when it was published in the Bihar Government Gazette.

facts.text: Bihar Act 7 of 1955 came into force on March 30, 1955, extending life of Act 7 of 1937 indefinitely beyond June 30, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, Bihar Act 7 of 1955 which came into force on March 30, 1955, amended s. 1 3  of Act 6 of 1950 extending the life of Act 7 of 1937, indefinitely beyond June 30, 1955.

facts.text: Essential Commodities Act No. 10 of 1955 (Central Act) came into force on April 1, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: In the mean- time, the Essential Commodities Act No. 10 of 1955  hereinafter called the Central Act  was enacted by Parliament. After the assent of the President, it came into force on April 1, 1955.

facts.text: Section 16(1)(b) of Central Act repealed other laws controlling production, supply etc. of essential commodities.

anchor.surface_text: Section 16 1   b  of the Central Act expressly repealed any other law in force in any State immediately before the companymencement of this Act in so far as such law companytrols or authorises the companytrol of the production, supply and distribution of, and trade and companymerce in, any essential companymodity.

facts.text: Bihar Act 17 of 1963 substituted Section 29 in Act 7 of 1937 with retrospective effect from January 1, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Bihar Act 17 of 1963 substituted in Act 7 of 1937 with retrospective effect from January 1, 1962, this new Section 29 Cess and tax on cane-The State Government may by numberification impose-  a  a cess number exceeding fifty-one naya paise per quintal on the entry of sugarcane into a local area, specified in such numberification, for companysumption, use or sale therein  b  a tax number exceeding fifty-one naya paise per quintal on the purchase of sugarcane by or on behalf of the occupier of a factory

facts.text: Government of Bihar issued notification on October 21, 1963 levying cane cess and purchase tax.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Bihar, acting under this Section, issued and published a numberification on October 21, 1963, in the Gazette whereby cane cess and purchase tax at certain rates were levied in the local areas specified in the numberification.

facts.text: Patna High Court by judgment dated July 4, 1966 in A. K. Jain v. Union of India held Act 7 of 1937 unconstitutional.

anchor.surface_text: The companystitutional validity of Bihar Act 7 of 1937 and the rules framed thereunder was challenged by a writ petition in the High Court of Patna which by its judgment, dated July 4, 1966, in A. K. Jain and anr. v. Union of India, 1  held Act 7 of 1937 and the rules framed thereunder to be unconstitutional and invalid.

facts.text: Supreme Court in A. K. Jain v. Union of India held Bihar Act 7 of 1937 altered if contrary to Rule 3(3) of Sugarcane Control Order 1955.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal against that  1  1968 Pat. Law Journal Reports p. 179 judgment this Court in A. K. Jain and others v. Union of India and ors.  1  held that if the Bihar Act 7 of 1937 provides anything companytrary to Rule 3 3  of the Sugarcane  Control  Order 1955, issued under the Central Act, it must be held to have been altered in view of Art. 372 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Ordinance No. 3 of 1968 promulgated by Governor of Bihar on January 12, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: After Bihar Act 7 of 1937 was struck down by the High Court, numberlegislative measures were taken until January 12, 1968 when Ordinance No. 3 was promulgated by the Governor of Bihar with instructions of the President.

facts.text: Notification under Ordinance 3 of 1968 issued on February 16, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: A numberification under s. 35 imposing a tax under this Ordinance 3 of 1968, however, was issued by the Government on February 16, 1968.

facts.text: Ordinance No. 3 lapsed on February 28, 1968; Ordinance No. 6 of 1968 promulgated same date.

anchor.surface_text: Ordinance No. 3 lapsed on February 28, 1968, on which date, another Ordinance  No. 6 of 1968  was promulgated.

facts.text: Petitioner purchased sugarcane in January 1968 for production of sugar from growers of allotted area at price fixed by State Government.

anchor.surface_text: In January 1968, the petitioner purchased sugarcane for production of sugar in its factory from the sugarcane growers of the area allotted to its factory on payment of the price fixed by the State Government.

facts.text: Respondent 1 sent four requisitions for realization of cane cess and purchase tax under Bihar Act 7 of 1937.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent 1 sent four requisitions for realization of cane cess and purchase tax said to be due under the Bihar Act 7 of 1937.

facts.text: Demand notices issued under s.5 of Bihar and Orissa Public Demands Recovery Act 1914; one for Rs. 1,71,543/56P for January 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The demand numberices were issued under s.5 of the Bihar and Orissa Public Demands Recovery Act 4 of 1914. One of such numberices was a demand of Rs. 1,71,543/56P. alleged to be cess purchase tax dues for January, 1968.

facts.text: Bihar Ordinance 4 of 1969 promulgated on July 4, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: On July 4, 1968, the Governor promulgated Bihar Ordinance 4 of 1969.

facts.text: Bihar Sugarcane Regulation of Supply and Purchase Act, 1969 (President's Act 8 of 1969) passed on August 31, 1969 during President's Rule.

anchor.surface_text: On August 31, 1969 during the Presidents Rule, Bihar Sugarcane  Regulation of Supply and Purchase  Act, 1969  Presidents Act 8 of 1969  was passed.

facts.text: Patna High Court followed A.K. Jain in Sugauli Sugar Works Pvt. Ltd. v. Cooperative Development and Cane Marketing Union.

anchor.surface_text: The Patna High Court followed its earlier decision in A. K. Jains case, in Sugauli Sugar Works Pvt. Ltd. v. Cooperative Development and Cane Marketing Union 2  and in Belsand Sugar Co. Ltd. v. Thakur Girja Nandan Singh 3 .

facts.text: Petitioner contends no law authorizing levy till January 12, 1968 when Ordinance 6 promulgated.

anchor.surface_text: There was numberlaw in force authorising the levy of the cess tax till January 12, 1968 when Bihar Ordinance 6 of 1968 was promulgated

facts.text: Petitioner contends 2nd proviso to s.35 of Ordinance 6 of 1968 invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The 2nd proviso to s.35 of Bihar Ordinance 6 of 1968 is invalid.

facts.text: Court holds taxing provisions of Bihar Act 7 of 1937 continued valid after Central Act 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The taxing provisions of the Bihar Act were number in any way repugnant to the Central Act or any other law passed by Parliament. Those taxing provisions, as already numbericed, fall under Entry 52, List II and that was why s.16 of the Central Act companyfined the repeal only to those provisions which were companyered by Entry 33, list Ill.

facts.text: Notification imposing tax issued on October 21, 1963 continued operative till replaced on January 12, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The numberification issued under the Bihar Acts of 1937,  and companytinued under the Acts of 1955 and 1963 , imposing the tax or cess, also remained operative during the period in question,. till it was replaced by another numberification issued on January 12, 1968 under the Ordinance 3 of 1968.

issues.text: Whether the Bihar Ordinance 3 of 1968 was beyond the competence of the Governor under Article 213 of the Constitution because there was no urgency for the promulgation of the Ordinance and the power was exercised malafide

Whether the 2nd proviso to s.35 of Bihar Ordinance 6 of 1968 is invalid and cannot give retrospective effect to the notification dated February 16, 1968 imposing tax under sections that only empower prospectively

anchor.surface_text: The 2nd proviso to s.35 of Bihar Ordinance 6 of 1968 is invalid. Section 35 of Ordinance 3 and 6 of 1968 per se did number impose any tax. It only empowered the State Government to do so by numberification, and that too prospectively. The second proviso cannot operate to give retrospective effect to the numberification, dated February 16, 1968.

issues.text: Whether after the commencement of the Central Act on April 1, 1955, the whole of Act 7 of 1937 became void and inoperative
To what extent this pre-Constitution Act 7 of 1937 was repugnant to the Central Act, and, in consequence stood repealed or altered
Whether there was no law or notification authorising levy of cess and tax for the period January 1 to 11, 1968

anchor.surface_text: Assuming this proviso to be valid, there was numbernotification imposing the tax, in existence for the period from January 1, 1968 to January 11, 1968. Any tax or cess levied for this uncovered period was without the authority of law The Bihar Ordinance 3 of 1968 was beyond the companypetence

issues.text: Whether the taxing provisions of Bihar Act 7 of 1937 continued valid despite repugnancy issues and prior judgments

arguments.claim: Bihar Act 7 of 1937 and Act 7 of 1955 and the notification imposing cess and tax were declared unconstitutional and invalid by Patna High Court in A.K. Jain case and affirmed by Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: Bihar Act 7 of 1937 and Act 7 of 1955 which attempted to make it permanent and the notification issued thereunder imposing the cess and tax in question, were declared unconstitutional and invalid by the Patna High Court in A. K. Jains case supra on July 4, 1966 and that decision was affirmed by this Court in appeal.

arguments.court_reasoning: Prior cases concerned only regulatory provisions under Entry 33 Concurrent List, not severable taxing provisions under Entry 52 State List; Supreme Court in A.K. Jain did not address taxing provisions

arguments.claim: There was no law in force authorising the levy of the cess and tax till January 12, 1968 when Bihar Ordinance 6 of 1968 was promulgated

anchor.surface_text: There was no law in force authorising the levy of the cess tax till January 12, 1968 when Bihar Ordinance 6 of 1968 was promulgated

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e by Article 254 1 , number repealed or altered by the companypetent Legislature within the companytemplation of Article 372 of the Constitution. It i

arguments.court_reasoning: Taxing provisions of Bihar Act 7 of 1937 continued valid and operative; notification of Oct 21, 1963 remained in force till replaced on Jan 12, 1968

arguments.claim: The 2nd proviso to s.35 of Bihar Ordinance 6 of 1968 is invalid as sections only empower prospective notification, cannot give retrospective effect to Feb 16, 1968 notification

anchor.surface_text: The 2nd proviso to s.35 of Bihar Ordinance 6 of 1968 is invalid. Section 35 of Ordinance 3 and 6 of 1968 per se did not impose any tax. It only empowered the State Government to do so by notification, and that too prospectively. The second proviso cannot operate to give retrospective effect to the notification, dated February 16, 1968.

arguments.court_reasoning: Legislature has power to validate retrospectively; s.66 of President's Act validates all past impositions with widest amplitude

arguments.claim: Second proviso antedates imposition of tax from January 12, 1968 date of Ordinance 3

anchor.surface_text: The second proviso to s.35 of Ordinance 6 of 1968 antedated the imposition of tax from January 12, 1968, the date of promulgation of the first Ordinance 3 of 1968.

arguments.court_reasoning: Prior taxing provisions and notifications already covered the period; validating acts deem impositions valid from material times

arguments.claim: No notification imposing tax for period January 1 to 11, 1968; levy without authority of law

anchor.surface_text: Assuming this proviso to be valid, there was no notification imposing the tax, in existence for the period from January 1, 1968 to January 11, 1968. Any tax or cess levied for this uncovered period was without the authority of law

arguments.qualifiers: Assuming this proviso to be valid

arguments.court_reasoning: 1963 notification under Bihar Act continued operative till replaced by Jan 12, 1968 notification under Ordinance 3

arguments.claim: Bihar Ordinance 3 of 1968 beyond competence of Governor under Article 213 due to no urgency and exercised malafide

anchor.surface_text: The Bihar Ordinance 3 of 1968 was beyond the competence of the Governor under Article 213 of the Constitution because there was no urgency for, the promulgation of the Ordinance and the power was exercised malafide-.

arguments.court_reasoning: Governor's subjective satisfaction on necessity not justiciable; precedent in State of Punjab v. Sat Pal Dang

arguments.claim: After commencement of Central Act on April 1, 1955, whole of Act 7 of 1937 became void and inoperative
arguments.court_reasoning: Only regulatory parts repugnant under Art 254 and repealed under s.16(1)(b); taxing parts severable and under state list

arguments.claim: Act 7 of 1937 provisions contrary to Sugarcane Control Order Rule 3(3) altered by Art 372

anchor.surface_text: On appeal against that judgment this Court in A. K. Jain and others v. Union of India and ors. held that if the Bihar Act 7 of 1937 provides anything contrary to Rule 3 3 of the Sugarcane Control Order 1955, issued under the Central Act, it must be held to have been altered in view of Art. 372 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Taxing provisions of Bihar Act severable from regulatory provisions; regulatory repugnant to Central Act but taxing valid under Entry 52 List II
s.16(1)(b) Central Act confined repeal to provisions covered by Entry 33 List III, not taxing under Entry 52 List II
Notification under Bihar Acts imposing tax remained operative till Jan 12, 1968

anchor.surface_text: The notification issued under the Bihar Acts of 1937, and continued under the Acts of 1955 and 1963, imposing the tax or cess, also remained operative during the period in question, till it was replaced by another notification issued on January 12, 1968 under the Ordinance 3 of 1968.

arguments.claim: Patna High Court in A.K. Jain struck down Bihar Act in entirety including taxing provisions
arguments.court_reasoning: Observations confined to regulatory parts; taxing provisions not at issue; severable; Supreme Court did not endorse broad proposition

arguments.claim: Governor's power under Art 213 subject to subjective satisfaction on urgency, not justiciable
Legislature has power to impose tax retrospectively or validate past collections
Bihar Act 7 of 1937 and rules unconstitutional and invalid

anchor.surface_text: The constitutional validity of Bihar Act 7 of 1937 and the rules framed thereunder was challenged by a writ petition in the High Court of Patna which by its judgment, dated July 4, 1966, in A. K. Jain and anr. v. Union of India, held Act 7 of 1937 and the rules framed thereunder to be unconstitutional and invalid.

arguments.court_reasoning: Accepted for regulatory parts but rejected for taxing parts as severable and not repugnant

holdings.text: The necessity of immediate action and of promulgating an Ordinance is a matter purely for the subjective satisfaction of the Governor; his satisfaction is not a justiciable matter.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Governor's power under Art. 213 subject to subjective satisfaction on urgency, not reviewable by court; cites precedent State of Punjab v. Sat Pal Dang.

holdings.text: After commencement of Central Act on April 1, 1955, the whole of Bihar Act 7 of 1937 did not become void; only regulatory provisions repugnant and repealed, taxing provisions continued valid.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Act deals with distinct matters: regulation (Entry 33 List III, repugnant under Art.254, repealed by s.16(1)(b)) vs. taxing (Entry 52 List II, not repugnant); s.16 confines repeal to control provisions.

holdings.text: Taxing provisions of Bihar Act 7 of 1937 not repugnant to Central Act, fall under Entry 52 List II, continued in force post-1955.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Regulatory (Entry 33) vs. taxing (Entry 52) severable; Central Act targets only control of essentials, not taxes; Art.372 alters only inconsistent parts.

holdings.text: Notification under Bihar Act 7 of 1937 (Oct 21, 1963) imposing cess and tax remained operative till replaced on January 12, 1968.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior notification valid under continuing taxing provisions; no gap in authority for January 1968 levy.

holdings.text: Patna High Court judgments (A.K. Jain etc.) and Supreme Court appeal did not invalidate taxing provisions of Bihar Act 7 of 1937.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior cases concerned only regulatory provisions (Entry 33); taxing (Entry 52) not at issue, severable; Supreme Court observations limited.

holdings.text: Second proviso to s.35 Ordinance 6 of 1968 and validating s.66(1) President's Act 8 of 1969 valid; legislature can impose tax or validate retrospectively.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Validation ancillary to legislative power; s.66 deems past impositions valid as if Act in force at material times, widest amplitude.

holdings.text: All contentions rejected; cane cess and purchase tax for January 1968 valid; writ petition dismissed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of above holdings upholds levy under continuing/validated provisions.
